captions.text:
Over 1.5 billion people use the internet every
day, and they search for pretty much anything.

Like “Why are barns red?” and “What’s
up with gluten?”

We here at SciShow are all about fostering
curiosity. That’s why we’ve worked with

Google and YouTube to answer ten of the most
popular questions searched on the internet.
This is The World’s Most Asked Questions.
Today’s question: What is love?

It’s the kind of thing that keeps poets
and philosophers up at night, but science

actually has a pretty good explanation for
it, too.
Actually, several explanations.

And the answer might change depending on what
kind of scientist you ask. A biologist would

say it’s all about reproduction, and the
evolution and survival of a species. A psychologist

may go on about our need for togetherness
and acceptance.

But possibly the best way to understand love
is through chemistry. Brain chemistry.

Although the heart is our symbol of love for
some reason, when it comes down to it, love
is all about the brain.

We know this because we can actually see love
in action in brain scans.

And you know what? It looks a awful like a
brain on cocaine.

As a person first falls in love, at least
a dozen different brain parts light up to

release powerful chemicals -- hormones and
neurotransmitters -- that trigger feelings
of excitement, euphoria, bonding, and butterflies.

Research also shows that the kind of unconditional
love between a mother and child activates
slightly different regions of the brain.

Early romantic love and attraction, what you
might call passion, is all about flooding

the brain’s reward systems in a tsunami
of feel-good chemicals like adrenaline, norepinephrine,
and dopamine.

This is why a brain on intense new love looks
a whole lot like a brain on coke -- adrenaline

and norepinephrine amp up your heart rate
and get you all restless, while those dopamine
drips leave you feeling euphoric.

These chemicals light up your brain’s pleasure
centers, lowering your pleasure thresholds,

and making it easier to feel good about...
everything.

Interestingly, this kind of passionate new
love is also marked by lowered serotonin levels,

similar to those found in people with obsessive-compulsive
disorders -- which may help explain those

30 texts your infatuated new lover sent while
you were in the shower.

Eventually, most of these more intense, obsessive
components of new love settle down into a

deeper, calmer form of love associated with
attachment and bonding. Here your brain chemistry

starts changing again, and hormones -- like
oxytocin and vasopressin -- take over.

Their mission, like Al Green’s, is to get
you to stay together.

You may have heard of oxytocin, the so-called
the “cuddle hormone.” It gets released

during orgasms, and for women during childbirth,
and it helps cement bonds between people.

And you can think of vasopressin as the monogamy
hormone. And you know who’s taught us more
about how it works than anything else?

Prairie voles, one of the very few mammals
that mate for life.

After mating, a male vole’s brain gets flooded
with vasopressin, and essentially gets hooked

on his mate forever. The two then have lots
of sex, and all that tiny boot-knocking keeps
the vasopressin flowing.

When researchers gave voles a compound that
suppressed the effects of vasopressin, the

pairs quickly fell apart, losing their devotion
to each other.

So, while in the poetic sense, love may always
be something of a mystery, from the scientific
view, it is within the realm of comprehension.

But what about you? How are the love lives
of the SciShow viewers? Well, of our survey

takers, people within the ages of 51 and 60
are the most likely to have been in love.

People who got their energy most from exercise
were also more likely to have been in love.

On the other hand, people who said they got
their energy from food were less likely to
have been in love.

Of all the fascinating questions in the world,
what question do you want answered most? Let

us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the comments
down below, and we will answer the best questions

in a new video at the end of the month. And
don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ and
stay tuned for other videos this week.

title: World’s Most Asked Questions: What Is Love?

comments.text:
What about Asexuals and Aromatics? I'm slightly both but my chemicals are 
in line. I would like to say I have more testosterone then my peers because 
I have full body hair (head to toe) and a beard. I can stare a woman and I 
feel nothing. Maybe this aura of wonder and aw but never a lustful feeling. 
Same goes with men and everything else. I defiantly get way less of that 
feeling with males but I can see the difference between an ugly person and 
a cute person. I don't get "turned on" by anything. I might feel a urge for 
hugging or cuddling but I don't want to have intercourse. Kissing makes me 
want to throw up and any sexual contact repulses me. I don't feel 
uncomfortable talking about it or seeing it. It just bothers me thinking 
about me and another person. I hate when women play hard to get. It makes 
me less attracted to them and actually angry and impatient. You don't play 
hard to get when you meet a co worker or schoolmate. So why the hell would 
you waste time on a potential partner? Again, I'm not like a lot of people. 
So I don't assume you would ever fully understand my frustrations with a 
very over sexual world that thinks you have a mental illness if you are not 
conforming.﻿

comments.text:
Shakespeare:
Sonnet CXVI
Let me not to the marriage of true minds
Admit impediments. Love is not love
Which alters when it alteration finds,
Or bends with the remover to remove:
O, no! it is an ever-fixed mark,
That looks on tempests and is never shaken;
It is the star to every wandering bark,
Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken.
Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks
Within his bending sickle's compass come;
Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,
But bears it out even to the edge of doom.
If this be error and upon me proved,
I never writ, nor no man ever loved.﻿

comments.author: TheFi0r3

comments.text:
I think the answer to the question will change depending on what kind of 
love you are wondering about. The definitions of love itself are usually 
vague or at least expressed by individuals according to their experiences 
and beliefs.
For example, one of the four loves described in the Bible is known as 
"agape" and the most used form of love in the text. This love is strictly 
not an emotion, not a feeling, and therefore not related at all to 
chemicals. Agape love is defined as a longstanding care for another person, 
and is characterized by the constant searching for the best in that person. 
This love is a chioce and a commitment which can be extended to anyone. By 
this standard of love, you can love friends, family, strangers, and 
literally everyone in existence.

Obviously, love as a human word and concept is not so easy to pin down ;)﻿

comments.text:
Love is security, and no, i'm not talking about the brinks security system. 
It's about feeling secure, secure in someone's mind, secure in someone's 
personality, secure in your own mind that you love someone, and in that 
case, that is what is known as a crush, it's selfish and the mind knows 
that it's bullshit and you're just lying to yourself, which explains the 
whole reason why you don't do anything about it.
You have to feel secure in the thought, to feel secure. Which is why when a 
man takes care of a woman, he knows he's secure in protecting her. But 
after she decides that she wants to get a job too, that security goes away. 
i.e. love. She is not secure if she decides to get a job as well, pretty 
self explanatory. Now it's not, I'm doing things for you type of 
relationship, now it's, I'm doing things for myself but let's just work 
together, like roommates or neighbors. but when the going gets tough, ill 
be on my way. where's the security? Where's the love? there is none.﻿
